Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Architecture for Ecosystems

(2) Summary

Digitale Transformation, APIs und Microservices waren nie gedacht als ein Weg, um IT Architektur und komplexe IT Landschaften zu vereinfachen. Sie sind primär eine Antwort auf zunehmende Komplexität und den Bedarf nach grösserer Flexibilität und kürzeren Entwicklungszyklen. In diesem Spannungsfeld verändern sich Rollen und Aufgaben in der Architektur. Zwischen Enterprise und Software Architekt geht es nun weniger darum, zentralistisch Lösungen bereitzustellen, sondern darum, ein Umfeld bereitzustellen, in dem dezentrale Lösungen effektiv umgesetzt werden können. "Continuous Architecting" verspricht, diese neue Aufgabenteilung zwischen Architekten besser zu unterstützen. Der Fokus ist dabei darauf, die Organisation als ein Ökosystem zu verstehen. Aufgabe des Enterprise Architekten ist es, das Ökosystem kontinuierlich zu beobachten, Rücksprache mit Entwicklern zu halten, und das System auf kontinuierliche Weise effizienter zu gestalten.

(5) About Me

  • Ph.D. in Communications Systems [http://dret.net/netdret/publications#wil97b] from ETH Zürich [http://www.ethz.ch/] (1997)
  • Research work at ETH Zürich [http://www.ethz.ch/] (1997-2006) and UC Berkeley [http://www.berkeley.edu/] (2006-2011)
  • EMC (2011-2014), working on transforming software products into service platforms
  • Siemens (2014-2015), working on using IoT to build WoT (APIs for Things)
  • Part of CA [http://www.ca.com/]'s API Academy [http://www.apiacademy.co/] 2016-2019 focusing on API Design and Management
  • Joined Good API [https://www.goodapi.co/] in 2019 focusing on Digital Transformation and API Strategy
  • Joined Axway [https://www.axway.com/]'s Catalysts [https://www.axway.com/services/catalysts] in 2019 for driving the Accelerate program [https://accelerate.axway.com/]
  • Active in the usual places such as Twitter [http://twitter.com/dret], GitHub [http://github.com/dret], and LinkedIn [http://www.linkedin.com/in/netdret]

(10) Digital Transformation Definition

Digital Transformation means adapting an organization's strategy and structure to capture opportunities enabled by digital technology. (Nathan Furr and Andrew Shipilov, Digital Doesn't Have to Be Disruptive, Harvard Business Review 97(4), July/August 2019, pp. 94-103) [https://hbr.org/2019/07/digital-doesnt-have-to-be-disruptive]

(17) Digital Transformation is Continuous

  • Digital transformation happens at two different levels
    • Transforming the organization to become better at adapting to changes
    • Identifying and implementing capabilities that improve the organization
  • You're never done with digital transformation
    • Business must be empowered and capable to identify opportunities
    • Organization must be capable of acting fast to capture opportunities
    • Technology must be able to realize opportunities quickly and safely

Continuous Architecting Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:

(21) The Essence of Continuous Architecting

  • Architecture is informed by solutions
  • Architecture's job is to support solutions
  • Architecture's job is to optimize the solution landscape
  • Architecture focuses on solution interfaces
    • Strictly separate interface and implementation architecture


Continuous Architecting Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Architecture for Ecosystems

(22) Emerging API Patterns

  • Problem details [http://webconcepts.info/specs/IETF/RFC/7807] as a way how APIs expose error information
    • Enables generic error handling but also allows additional information
  • Home documents [http://webconcepts.info/specs/IETF/I-D/nottingham-json-home] as a way how APIs provide starting pages
    • Enables harvesting of API start points but also allows additional information
  • Healthcheck reports [http://webconcepts.info/specs/IETF/I-D/inadarei-api-health-check] as a way how APIs expose status information
    • Enables landscape-level status reports but also allows additional information
  • API your APIs: Self-description for APIs is increasing
    • Design-time allows automation of API landscape overview
    • Runtime allows automation of API landscape status

API Landscape Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Architecture for Ecosystems

(24) Increasing Product Team Productivity

  • API product teams need guidance, autonomy, and support
    • Guidance helps understanding and navigating the current landscape
    • Autonomy allows choices to be made driven by product and user needs
    • Support increases productivity of teams for cross-cutting concerns
  • Balancing product value and product portfolio value
    • Products focus on achieving local maxima for product value
    • Landscapes focus on achieving global maxima across all products


API Landscape Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Architecture for Ecosystems

(25) CAM Landscape Compass



API Landscape Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Architecture for Ecosystems

(26) CAM Product Compass: Aspects 1-4

  • Variety example: How easy is it for your landscape to embrace and support a new API technology?
  • Vocabulary example: Is there an easy way for developers to discover the vocabularies that are in use throughout existing APIs?
  • Volume example: How easy is it for developers to design, implement, and deploy a new product?
  • Velocity example: Does anything in the API landscape slow down teams when creating or changing APIs?


API Landscape Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Architecture for Ecosystems

(27) CAM Product Compass: Aspects 5-8

  • Vulnerability example: Are APIs designed from the ground up to be potentially externalizable?
  • Visibility example: How easy it is for architects, teams, and consumers to explore the entire API landscape?
  • Versioning example: Are APIs designed and implemented so that changes create as little disruption as possible?
  • Volatility example: Are all dependencies implemented to be visible and to behave responsibly when some APIs fail?


API Landscape Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Architecture for Ecosystems

Architecture for Ecosystems

(30) Product Pillars and Maturity

  • API Products are created in the context of (possibly implicit) API landscapes
    • They are influenced by the culture and constraints of the landscape
  • Product Pillars identify areas of investment during an API's lifetime
  • Product Maturity describes stages of an API product's lifetime


Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Architecture for Ecosystems

(31) CAM Product Compass



Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Architecture for Ecosystems

(32) CAM Product Compass: Maturity



Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Architecture for Ecosystems

(33) CAM Product Compass: Pillars 1-5

  • Change Management example: If your design includes a plan for evolving the API itself, do you document this clearly so that clients know what to expect?
  • Deployment example: Deployment is aligned with the change management principles, so that if necessary, multiple versions can be operated and potentially discovered in parallel.
  • Design example: Given the API's style and technology, is it using a recommended and/or standardized description format that makes it easier for consumers to gain an initial understanding of the API, possibly aided by tooling they can use?
  • Development example: Does development include technologies and/or tools that are not part of the recommended development technologies and/or tools in the organization?
  • Discovery example: Based on the change management strategy, it is made sure that it is always the most recent version that is made available through all discovery channels.


Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Architecture for Ecosystems

(34) CAM Product Compass: Pillars 6-10

  • Documentation example: Is the documentation and learning experience for the API based on the strategic goals of the API product?
  • Monitoring example: Is all the monitoring information collected in a way that it can be easily accessed and reused?
  • Security example: Documentation and design expose as little information about implementation details as possible to reduce the attack surface.
  • Strategy example: Do you have a clearly defined and documented reason why the API exists?
  • Testing example: Do your tests include scenarios where consumed APIs are not performing or are not reachable, in order to test for resiliency of the API product?


Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Architecture for Ecosystems

Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Architecture for Ecosystems

(37) Practicing Continuous Architecting

  • Create rules what to do and not how to do it
  • When you say what to do also explain why this constraint exists
  • Propose/suggest/support at least one way how to satisfy the constraint
  • Be open to new ways of how constraints can be satisfied
  • Explain how to verify compliance with the constraint


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Architecture for Ecosystems
